summary: Airlines sometimes overbook flights, which can mean they have to deny boarding to some passengers. Generally, fewer passengers have been denied boarding in recent years, with less than 1% of passengers affected. Passengers may volunteer to give up a seat in exchange for some benefit from the airline, like a travel voucher. Passengers who don’t volunteer and are denied boarding anyway—involuntarily denied boarding or “bumped”—can...
title: Airline Consumer Protections: Information on Airlines' Denied Boarding Practices
